Abstract: This study delves into the multifaceted issue of food insecurity in the United States, focusing on its measurement, economic modeling, and the effectiveness of food assistance programs. Utilizing a comprehensive review of existing literature and data analysis, we explore the nuances of food and nutrition security, highlighting the critical role of federal assistance programs such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), the School Breakfast Program (SBP), the National School Lunch Program (NSLP), and the Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) program. Our analysis reveals the complex interplay between economic factors, policy interventions, and nutritional outcomes, underscoring the importance of accurate measurement tools and robust economic models to assess and address food insecurity. Furthermore, we evaluate the impact of these programs on alleviating food insecurity among vulnerable populations, offering insights into their strengths and areas for improvement. This research contributes to the ongoing discourse on food security by providing evidence-based recommendations for enhancing the effectiveness of food assistance initiatives, ultimately aiming to reduce food insecurity and improve nutritional well-being across the United States.
